name.text: Calculating the area of a rhombus

questiontext.text:
The perimeter of a rhombus is \({@Perimeter@}\,\text{m}\). One of its diagonals is \({@One_diagonal@}\,\text{m}\). Answer the following:

  1. Find the length of the other diagonal.

    \(\text{The other diagonal} = \) [[input:ans1]] \(\text{m}\) [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. Find the area of the rhombus.

    \(\text{Area} = \) [[input:ans2]] \(\text{m}^2\) [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
To answer the above question follow the following steps

Step 1: Find the length of one side

A rhombus has 4 equal sides. Therefore,
\(\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=4 \times \text{side} \\ {@Perimeter@} &=4 \times \text{side} \\ \text{side}=\frac{{@Perimeter@}}{4} \\ &={@c@}\, \text{m} \end{align}\)

Step 2: Use the diagonal property

The diagonals of a rhombus cut each other into two equal parts and form right angles.
\(\bullet\) One diagonal \(={@One_diagonal@}\, \text{m}\), so half of it \(=\frac{{@One_diagonal@}}{2}={@a@}\).
\(\bullet\) Let the other diagonal \(=d_2\). Then half of it \(= \frac{d_2}{2}\).

Using Pythagorasâ€™ Theorem:
\( \begin{align} {@c@}^2&= \left ( \frac{{@One_diagonal@}}{2}\right )^2+\left ( \frac{d_2}{2}\right )^2\\ \left ( \frac{d_2}{2}\right )^2&={@c@}^2- \left ({@a@} \right )^2\\ d_2&=2 \times \sqrt{ {@c@}^2- \left ({@a@} \right )^2 } \\ \text{So, the other diagonal is:} \\ d_2&={@other_diagonal@}\,\text{m} \end{align}\)

Step 3: Find the area of the rhombus

The formula for the area is: \(\text{Area}=\frac{d_1 \times d_2}{2}\)
Therefore;

\(\begin{align} \text{Area}&=\frac{{@One_diagonal@} \times {@other_diagonal@}}{2}\\ &={@Area_of_Rhombus@}\, \text{m}^2 \end{align}\)

Therefore:
The length of the other diagonal is: \({@other_diagonal@}\,\text{m} \)
The area of the rhombus is: \( {@Area_of_Rhombus@}\, \text{m}^2\)
